tit.e: Ioto no miya (Ioto Palace, an imperial palace in the capital of ancient Japan [in the early days of the Yamato dynasty])

sen.j: 庵戸宮（廬戸宮）（いおとのみや）は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に伝わる古代日本(ヤマト王権初期)の首都として営まれた皇宮（皇居）。
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ioto no miya was a kogu (Imperial Palace) established in the capital of the ancient Japan (early Yamato sovereignty, the ancient Japan sovereignty).

According to the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ioto no miya was a kogu (imperial palace) established in the capital of ancient Japan (in the early days of the Yamato dynasty).

According to the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ioto no miya was an imperial palace established in the capital of ancient Japan (in the early days of the Yamato dynasty).

sen.j: 第6代孝安天皇暦102年（紀元前291年）に、第7代孝霊天皇により現在の奈良県磯城郡田原本町黒田周辺の地に遷都されたと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is told that the seventh Emperor Korei transferred the capital to the place around the current Kuroda area in Tawaramoto-cho Town, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture and established Ioto no miya in 291 B.C.

Legend has it that the seventh Emperor, Korei, transferred the capital to a place near an area of present-day Tawaramoto-cho Town (Shiki County, Nara Prefecture) called Kuroda, establishing Ioto no miya there in 291 B.C.

Legend has it that the seventh Emperor, Korei, transferred the capital to a place near an area of present-day Kuroda in Tawaramoto-cho Town (Shiki County, Nara Prefecture), establishing Ioto no miya there in 291 B.C.

sen.j: そのため、黒田庵戸宮ともいわれる。
sen.e: Therefore, Ioto no miya is also called Kuroda Ioto no miya.
As a result, Ioto no miya is also called Kuroda Ioto no miya.
As a result, Ioto no miya is also called Kuroda Ioto no miya.

sen.j: ただし、正確な所在地については諸説ある。
sen.e: However, there are various views about the accurate location of Ioto no miya.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, opinions vary as to its true location.
However, opinions vary as to its true location.

sen.j: （奈良県史料『大和志料』によると黒田ではなく同町字宮古であるとか、「いおと」という読みから同字伊与戸に置かれたとする説がある。)
sen.e: (According to the "Yamato Shiryo," the historical sources of Nara Prefecture, one suggestion is that it was located in not Kuroda but aza Miyako [Miyako block] in the town, and the other suggestion is that it was located in Iyoto in the aza guessing from the pronunciation 'i-o-to.')
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。「奈良県史料」は定訳不明のため、"historical sources of Nara Prefecture"としました。
sen.e: (According to the "Yamato Shiryo," the historical sources of Nara Prefecture, one suggestion is that it was located in not Kuroda but aza Miyako [Miyako block] in the same town, and the other suggestion is that it was located in Iyoto in the aza guessing from the pronunciation 'i-o-to.')
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: (According to the "Yamato Shiryo," the historical sources of Nara Prefecture, one suggestion is that it was located in not Kuroda but aza Miyako [Miyako block] in the same town, and the other suggestion is that it was located in Iyoto in the aza guessing from the pronunciation 'i-o-to.')

sen.j: いずれにしても、孝霊天皇以前の皇宮の多くが奈良県山間部に置かれたと伝わるのに対して、奈良県中央に位置する奈良盆地に遷都されたことで、大和国から河内国への進出、吉備国平定など黎明期のヤマト王権の支配域拡大につながったものとみられている。
sen.e: In either case, while it is told that many Imperial Palaces built before Emperor Korei were located in the mountain area of Nara Prefecture, relocation of the capital to Ioto no miya in the Nara basin located in the center of Nara Prefecture is believed to enable early Yamato sovereignty to extend dominating areas including advance from Yamato Province to Kawachi Province and conquest of Kibi Province.

In either case, while legends have it that many imperial palaces built before Emperor Korei were located in the mountain area of Nara Prefecture, it is estimated that relocation of the capital to Ioto no miya to the Nara basin the center of Nara Prefecture enabled early Yamato dynasty to extend dominating areas including advance from Yamato Province to Kawachi Province and conquest of Kibi Province.

In either case, while legends have it that many imperial palaces built before Emperor Korei were located in the mountain area of Nara Prefecture, it is estimated that relocation of the capital to Ioto no miya to the Nara basin the center of Nara Prefecture enabled early Yamato dynasty to extend dominating areas including advance from Yamato Province to Kawachi Province and conquest of Kibi Province.

sen.j: 孝霊天皇暦76年（紀元前215年）2月に同天皇が崩御し、第8代孝元天皇により軽境原宮（かるのさかいはらのみや、現在の奈良県橿原市見瀬町周辺と伝えられる）に遷都されるまでの間、政権の中枢として機能したとみられる。
sen.e: It is believed that Ioto no miya functioned as the center of the government until when Emperor Korei died in February 215 B.C. and the eighth Emperor Kogen relocated the capital in Karu no sakaihara no miya (Karu no sakaihara Palace) that was placed in the vicinity of current Mise-cho Town, Kasihara City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It is believed that Ioto no miya functioned as the center of the government until when Emperor Korei died in March 215 B.C. and the eighth Emperor, Kogen, relocated the capital in Karu no sakaihara no miya (Karu no sakaihara Palace; that is said in the vicinity of current Mise-cho Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しスペル修正しました。
sen.e: It is believed that Ioto no miya functioned as the center of the government until when Emperor Korei died in March 215 B.C. and the eighth Emperor, Kogen, relocated the capital in Karu no sakaihara no miya (Karu no sakaihara Palace; that is said in the vicinity of current Mise-cho Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: （一方で、この時期は第9代開化天皇までのいわゆる欠史八代の期間にあたり、そもそも『古事記』『日本書紀』自体の信頼性を疑う見方も根強く存在する。）
sen.e: (On the other hand, since this period corresponds to so-called Kesshi-Hachidai [Eight Undocumented Sovereigns] to the era of the ninth Emperor Kaika, some views persist that the credibility of the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" themselves is doubtful in the first place.)
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: (On the other hand, since this period corresponds to so-called Kesshi-Hachidai [Eight Undocumented Sovereigns] to the era of the ninth Emperor, Kaika, some views persist that the credibility of the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" themselves is doubtful in the first place.)
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: (On the other hand, since this period corresponds to so-called Kesshi-Hachidai [Eight Undocumented Sovereigns] to the era of the ninth Emperor, Kaika, some views persist that the credibility of the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" themselves is doubtful in the first place.)

sen.j: 庵戸宮の「庵(廬)」とは、風流人など浮世離れした者や僧侶が執務に用いる質素な佇まいの小屋である庵室を指したり、あるいは軍隊を管理する陣営を指す（歴史辞書『和名類聚抄』）ことから、文字通り政権の統括者である孝霊天皇が暮らした住まいに由来するものといわれている。
sen.e: "Io" of Ioto no miya means "Anshitu", i.e. a humble cabin, which a person who lives a life aloof from the affairs of the world such as a person of refined taste, or a priest uses at work, or means a camp for controlling the army (adapted from "Wamyoruiju-sho" [Kango-Japanese Dictionary]), so that Ioto no miya is believed to be derived from the residence of Emperor Korei who was literally the governor of the government.

Io' of Ioto no miya refers to "Anshitsu," i.e. a humble cabin, which a person who lives a life aloof from the affairs of the world such as a person of refined taste, or a priest uses at work, or refers to a camp for controlling the army (adapted from "Wamyoruiju-sho" [famous Heian-period Japanese dictionary]), so that Ioto no miya is believed to be derived from the residence of Emperor Korei who was literally the governor of the government.
sen.cmt: カッコを半角にし、用語補足を修正しました。
sen.e: Io' of Ioto no miya refers to "Anshitsu," i.e. a humble cabin, which a person who lives a life aloof from the affairs of the world such as a person of refined taste, or a priest uses at work, or refers to a camp for controlling the army (adapted from "Wamyoruiju-sho" [famous Heian-period Japanese dictionary]), so that Ioto no miya is believed to be derived from the residence of Emperor Korei who was literally the governor of the government.

sen.j: 現在、奈良県や和歌山県を中心に「庵戸（いおと、あんど）」という名称が希少姓として数世帯存在する。
sen.e: At present, a few families having a rare surname 'Ioto (or Ando)' exist centered in Nara Prefecture or Wakayama Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: At present, a few families having a rare surname 'Ioto' (or Ando) exist centered in Nara Prefecture or Wakayama Prefecture.
At present, a few families having a rare surname 'Ioto' (or Ando) exist centered in Nara Prefecture or Wakayama Prefecture.

sen.j: （この一族は、第7代孝霊天皇の第3皇子を始祖とする末裔であると代々伝承されているが、名前が確認されている5人の皇子（孝元天皇、日子刺肩別命、彦五十狭芹彦命、彦狭島命、稚武彦命）のうち具体的に誰を示すのかは不明である）。
sen.e: (This clan is told for generations that descendants of the founder, the third prince of the seventh Emperor Korei, however it is not exactly known which prince was that among five princes whose names are identified [Emperor Kogen, Hikosashi Katawake no Mikoto, Hikoisaseribiko no Mikoto, Hikosashima no Mikoto, and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto.])
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: (This clan is told for generations that descendants of the founder, the third prince of the seventh Emperor, Korei, however it is not exactly known which prince was that among five princes whose names are identified [Emperor Kogen, Hikosashi Katawake no Mikoto, Hikoisaseribiko no Mikoto, Hikosashima no Mikoto, and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto].)
sen.cmt: スペース、ピリオド、カンマ等を変えました。
sen.e: (This clan is told for generations that descendants of the founder, the third prince of the seventh Emperor, Korei, however it is not exactly known which prince was that among five princes whose names are identified [Emperor Kogen, Hikosashi Katawake no Mikoto, Hikoisaseribiko no Mikoto, Hikosashima no Mikoto, and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto].)

sen.j: 奈良県磯城郡田原本町黒田に、庵戸神社（廬戸神社、孝霊神社）という神社があり、これが庵戸宮の伝承地とされている。
sen.e: There is a shrine called Ioto Shrine (Korei Shrine) in Kuroda, Tawaramoto-cho Town, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture, which is told the traditional place of Ioto no miya.
There is a shrine called Ioto-jinja Shrine (also known as Korei-jinja Shrine) in Kuroda, Tawaramoto-cho Town, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture, which is told the traditional place of Ioto no miya.
There is a shrine called Ioto-jinja Shrine (also known as Korei-jinja Shrine) in Kuroda, Tawaramoto-cho Town, Shiki County, Nara Prefecture, which is told the traditional place of Ioto no miya.

sen.j: ただし、もともとは鎮守社として同町の法楽寺（真言宗、聖徳太子開基）の境内にあったものが、明治時代初期の神仏分離令により現社地へ遷座し黒田村の氏神として引き継がれたという経緯（旧地より移した「明和7年(西暦1770年)」の紀年銘をもつ石燈籠１対により確認できる）の為、現在の庵戸神社は厳密には宮跡とはいえない。
sen.e: However, there is a background that it was originally located in precincts of Horaku-ji Temple (Shingon sect, founded by Prince Shotoku) in the town as a chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area), then transferred to the current place due to the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism in early Meiji period, and taken over as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) of Kuroda village, (it can be confirmed by a pair of Ishi-doro [stone lantern] with the inscription about counting year in 1770 of transferred year), so that the present location of Ioto Shrine is not the place site, to be exact.

However, since the shrine originally was located in precincts of Horaku-ji Temple (Shingonshu sect, founded by Prince Shotoku) in the same town as a chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area), then was transferred to the current place by the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism in early Meiji period to take over ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) of Kuroda village (confirmed by a pair of stone lantern with the inscription of the transferred year as '1770'), the present location of Ioto-jinja Shrine technically is not the palace site.

However, since the shrine originally was located in precincts of Horaku-ji Temple (Shingonshu sect, founded by Prince Shotoku) in the same town as a chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area), then was transferred to the current place by the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism in early Meiji period to take over ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) of Kuroda village (confirmed by a pair of stone lantern with the inscription of the transferred year as '1770'), the present location of Ioto-jinja Shrine technically is not the palace site.

sen.j: これに対して法楽寺には、庵戸宮跡であったことを示す石碑が建立されている。
sen.e: At the same time, there is a sekihi (stone monument) indicating that the place site of Ioto no miya in Horaku-ji Temple.
On the other hand, Horaku-ji Temple has a stone monument indicating that it is the palace site of Ioto no miya.
On the other hand, Horaku-ji Temple has a stone monument indicating that it is the palace site of Ioto no miya.

sen.j: かつてはここに25宇もの堂塔伽藍が建ち並んでいたが、承元元年（西暦1207年）に全て消失し、現在はわずかに1宇（貞応元年（1222年）に再建）が残るのみである。
sen.e: Horaku-ji Temple used to have 25 buildings of dotogaran (temple's halls, pagodas and cathedrals) but all of these were lost in 1207, and only one building (rebuilt in 1222) remains today.
Horaku-ji Temple had 25 buildings such as temple's halls, pagodas and cathedrals, which were all lost in 1207, and only one building (rebuilt in 1222) remains today.
Horaku-ji Temple had 25 buildings such as temple's halls, pagodas and cathedrals, which were all lost in 1207, and only one building (rebuilt in 1222) remains today.

sen.j: 庵戸神社には、祭神として孝霊天皇の他、倭迹迹日百襲姫命、彦五十狭芹彦命、稚武彦命をはじめとする皇子皇女を含めた計7神が祭られており、毎年10月9日に大祭式例祭が行われる。
sen.e: Ioto Shrine enshrines Emperor Korei as the deity and a total of seven deities including princes and princesses, such as Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, Hikoisaseribiko no Mikoto, and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, and conducts Taisaishikireisai (great annual festival) in every October 9th.

Ioto-jinja Shrine enshrines a total of seven gods including Emperor Korei, and other princes and princesses, such as Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto (Princess Yamatototohimomosohime), Hikoisaseribiko no Mikoto (Prince Hikoisaseribiko), and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto (Prince Wakatakehiko); Taisaishikireisai (great annual festival) is held in every October 9.

Ioto-jinja Shrine enshrines a total of seven gods including Emperor Korei, and other princes and princesses, such as Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto (Princess Yamatototohimomosohime), Hikoisaseribiko no Mikoto (Prince Hikoisaseribiko), and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto (Prince Wakatakehiko); Taisaishikireisai (great annual festival) is held in every October 9.

sen.j: 庵戸宮は、後述する伝説のように桃太郎と卑弥呼ゆかりの地とされているが、伝説を鵜呑みに捉えた場合、 桃太郎と卑弥呼は共に孝霊天皇の皇子皇女として兄妹であったということになり、それら兄妹の生誕の地としても伝えられている。
sen.e: Ioto no miya is told a place associated with Momotaro (Peach Boy, character of a Japanese folk tale) and Himiko (shaman queen of Yamataikoku (Yamatai Kingdom) in ancient Japan) as below described legends, and if accepting the legends on faith, Momotaro and Himiko were a brother and sister as a prince and princess of Emperor Korei, accordingly Ioto no miya is also told as a birthplace of the brother and sister.

Legend described later has it that Ioto no miya is a place associated with Momotaro (Peach Boy, character of a Japanese folk tale) and Himiko (shaman queen of Yamatai-Koku kingdom in ancient Japan), and if accepting the legend on faith, Momotaro and Himiko were siblings as a prince and princess of Emperor Korei, therefore Ioto no miya is also told as a birthplace of the siblings.

Legend described later has it that Ioto no miya is a place associated with Momotaro (Peach Boy, character of a Japanese folk tale) and Himiko (shaman queen of Yamatai-Koku kingdom in ancient Japan), and if accepting the legend on faith, Momotaro and Himiko were siblings as a prince and princess of Emperor Korei, therefore Ioto no miya is also told as a birthplace of the siblings.

sen.j: そのため、これらの伝説にちなんで（その信頼性はともかくとして）、共に物語の主役として人気のある桃太郎、卑弥呼というキャラクターを観光PRのマスコットとして利用する向きもある。
sen.e: Therefore, some people use Momotaro and Himiko, which are both popular leading characters of the legends, as mascots for tourism public relations based on the legends (leaving aside the credibility of them.)

Therefore, some people use Momotaro and Himiko, which are both popular leading characters of the legend, as mascots for tourism public relations based on the legend (leaving aside the credibility of them).

Therefore, some people use Momotaro and Himiko, which are both popular leading characters of the legend, as mascots for tourism public relations based on the legend (leaving aside the credibility of them).

tit.j: 桃太郎の誕生地としての伝説
tit.e: Legends about the birthplace of Momotaro
Legends about the birthplace of Momotaro
Legends about the birthplace of Momotaro

sen.j: 孝霊天皇の皇子彦五十狭芹彦命（ひこいさせりひこのみこと、吉備津彦命）、稚武彦命（わかたけひこのみこと）の兄弟は、ヤマト王権の将帥（四道将軍）として温羅（うら）と呼ばれる製鉄に優れた吉備国の武装勢力（地方豪族やそれに与する渡来人の集団と考えられている）を制圧するために吉備国に遠征しこれを平定したといわれている。
sen.e: It is told that Hikoisaserihiko no Mikoto (i.e. Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto) and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto brothers, who were princes of Emperor Korei, set off on the military expedition as commanders (Shido-shogun [Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits]) of Yamato sovereignty to Kibi Province to subdue the armed forces in Kibi Province, which were called Ura and had advanced iron making skills (they are considered as powerful local clans and cooperating groups of toraijin, i.e. settlers from overseas), and conquered them.

It is thought that Hikoisaserihiko no Mikoto (also known as Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto) and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto brothers, the princes of Emperor Korei, as commanders of Yamato dynasty (Shido-shogun [Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits]), toured to the Kibi Province to subdue Ura, who were the armed forces there and advanced iron making skills (they are considered as powerful local clans and cooperating groups of toraijin, i.e. settlers from overseas).

It is thought that Hikoisaserihiko no Mikoto (also known as Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto) and Wakatakehiko no Mikoto brothers, the princes of Emperor Korei, as commanders of Yamato dynasty (Shido-shogun [Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits]), toured to the Kibi Province to subdue Ura, who were the armed forces there and advanced iron making skills (they are considered as powerful local clans and cooperating groups of toraijin, i.e. settlers from overseas).

sen.j: さらに、両皇子の軍勢は讃岐国、出雲国にまで侵攻し、ヤマト王権の支配を拡大させたと考えられている。
sen.e: Further, troops of the both princes invaded Sanuki Province and Izumo Province, and thus it is believed that the domination by Yamato sovereignty was extended.
Further, troops of the both princes invaded Sanuki and Izumo Provinces, and thus it is believed that the domination by Yamato dynasty was expanded.
Further, troops of the both princes invaded Sanuki and Izumo Provinces, and thus it is believed that the domination by Yamato dynasty was expanded.

sen.j: ちなみに、このとき両皇子が連れて行った犬飼部、猿飼部、鳥飼部とよばれる役職の家臣の一人が、元首相犬養毅の祖先ともいわれる犬養健命（いぬかいたけるのみこと）であったといわれている。
sen.e: By the way, it is said that one of the vassals in the positions called Inukaibe (position for breeding hunting dogs and watchdogs), Sarukaibe, and Torikaibe, who followed the both princes, was Inukaitakeru no Mikoto, who was told the ancestor of former prime minister Tsuyoshi INUKAI.
sen.cmt: 「猿飼部」の定訳が不明でしたので、Sarukaibeとしました。「犬飼部」については大辞林第二版を参照しました。
sen.e: It is said, incidentally, that one of the vassals in the positions called Inukaibe (position for breeding hunting dogs and watchdogs), Sarukaibe (position for breeding monkeys), and Torikaibe (position for breeding birds), who followed the both princes on this occasion, was Inukaitakeru no Mikoto, who was told the ancestor of former prime minister Tsuyoshi INUKAI.
sen.cmt: 用語補足し、表現を変えました。
sen.e: It is said, incidentally, that one of the vassals in the positions called Inukaibe (position for breeding hunting dogs and watchdogs), Sarukaibe (position for breeding monkeys), and Torikaibe (position for breeding birds), who followed the both princes on this occasion, was Inukaitakeru no Mikoto, who was told the ancestor of former prime minister Tsuyoshi INUKAI.

sen.j: このような両皇子の活躍や当時のヤマト王権と吉備国との対立構図が、後世の桃太郎伝説の基礎となったのではないかとの見方が有力視されている。
sen.e: The view that such great successes of the both princes and a confrontational relation between Yamato sovereignty and Kibi Province in those days formed the basis of later legend of Momotaro is widely accepted

The view that such great successes of the both princes and a confrontational relation between Yamato dynasty and Kibi Province in those days formed the basis of later legend of Momotaro is widely accepted
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。
sen.e: The view that such great successes of the both princes and a confrontational relation between Yamato dynasty and Kibi Province in those days formed the basis of later legend of Momotaro is widely accepted

sen.j: これに関連してか、現在でも岡山県（吉備国）や香川県（讃岐国）では、両皇子をモデルとする桃太郎伝説や温羅を鬼とみなす伝説の伝承地が複数個所存在する。
sen.e: It may be associated with this view, there are several traditional places of the legend of Momotaro modeled on the both princes and legends which regards Ura as Oni (demon or ogre) in Okayama Prefecture (Kibi Province) and Kagawa Prefecture (Sanuki Province) even now.

It may be associated with this view; there are several traditional places of the legend of Momotaro modeled on the both princes and legends which regards Ura as Oni (demon or ogre) in Okayama Prefecture (Kibi Province) and Kagawa Prefecture (Sanuki Province) even now.

It may be associated with this view; there are several traditional places of the legend of Momotaro modeled on the both princes and legends which regards Ura as Oni (demon or ogre) in Okayama Prefecture (Kibi Province) and Kagawa Prefecture (Sanuki Province) even now.

sen.j: これらの古の伝承に由来して、両皇子の故郷ともいえる庵戸宮が桃太郎の生誕地として現在にも伝えられている。
sen.e: Based on these old traditions, Ioto no miya that was the home of the both princes is believed as the birthplace of Momotaro today.
Based on these old traditions, Ioto no miya that was the home of the both princes is believed as the birthplace of Momotaro today.
Based on these old traditions, Ioto no miya that was the home of the both princes is believed as the birthplace of Momotaro today.

sen.j: また、孝霊天皇自身による鬼退治の伝説や、庵戸宮近くを流れる大和川（初瀬川）周辺に伝わる下記のような伝説も存在する。
sen.e: In addition, there are the legend of Ogre extermination by Emperor Korei himself and the legend handed down around Yamato-gawa River (Hatsuse-gawa River) near Ioto no miya as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In addition, the legend of Oni extermination by Emperor Korei himself and following legend are handed down around the Yamato-gawa River (also known as the Hatsuse-gawa River) flowing near Ioto no miya.

In addition, the legend of Oni extermination by Emperor Korei himself and following legend are handed down around the Yamato-gawa River (also known as the Hatsuse-gawa River) flowing near Ioto no miya.

sen.j: 「昔大和国洪水の折に、初瀬川大いに漲り、大なる甕一つ流れ来たって三輪の社頭に止まる。」
sen.e: It said, 'once upon a time, when Yamato province had floods and the Hatsuse-gawa River swollen, a big pot floated down the river and stopped in front of Miwa Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。「三輪の社」は定訳不明のため、"Miwa shrine"としました。
sen.e: Once upon a time, when Yamato Province had floods and the Hatsuse-gawa River swollen, a big pot floated down the river and stopped in front of a shrine in Miwa.'
sen.cmt: 分割ルールに従いカッコを補足しました。
sen.e: Once upon a time, when Yamato Province had floods and the Hatsuse-gawa River swollen, a big pot floated down the river and stopped in front of a shrine in Miwa.'

sen.j: 「土人開き見るに玉の如き一男子あり云々。」
sen.e: When local people opened the pot, there was a pretty boy in it.
When local people opened the pot, there was a pretty boy in it.'
sen.cmt: 分割ルールに従いカッコを補足しました。
sen.e: When local people opened the pot, there was a pretty boy in it.'

sen.j: 「後に又小舟に乗って播磨国に着し、大荒明神となりけり。」（林羅山『本朝神社考』、柳田國男『桃太郎の誕生』）
sen.e: Later the boy rode a boat to Harima Province and became Osake myojin (God of Osake).' (adapted from Razan HAYASHI "Honcho Jinja Ko" [a study of Japanese shrine] and Kunio YANAGIDA "Momotaro no Tanjo" [The Origins of Momotaro])

Later the boy rode a small boat to Harima Province and became Osake myojin (God of Osake).' (adapted from Razan HAYASHI, "Honcho Jinja Ko" [a study of Japanese shrine] and Kunio YANAGIDA, "Momotaro no Tanjo" [The Origins of Momotaro])
sen.cmt: 分割ルールに従いカッコを補足しました。
sen.e: Later the boy rode a small boat to Harima Province and became Osake myojin (God of Osake).' (adapted from Razan HAYASHI, "Honcho Jinja Ko" [a study of Japanese shrine] and Kunio YANAGIDA, "Momotaro no Tanjo" [The Origins of Momotaro])

sen.j: 昔、大和の国が洪水になったとき、初瀬川が増水し、大きな瓶が一つ流れてきて三輪の神社の前に止まった。
sen.e: Once upon a time, when Yamato province had floods and the Hatsuse-gawa River swollen, a big pot floated down the river and stopped in front of Miwa Shrine.
sen.cmt: 前出列の現代語文で、同内容です。「三輪の神社」は定訳不明のため、"Miwa shrine"としました。
sen.e: Once upon a time, when Yamato Province had floods and the Hatsuse-gawa River swollen, a big pot floated down the river and stopped in front of a shrine in Miwa.
Once upon a time, when Yamato Province had floods and the Hatsuse-gawa River swollen, a big pot floated down the river and stopped in front of a shrine in Miwa.

sen.j: 土地の者がそれを割って中を見ると玉のような一人の男の子がいた～。
sen.e: When local people opened the pot, there was a pretty boy in it.
sen.cmt: 前出列の現代語文で、同内容です。
sen.e: When local people opened the pot, there was a pretty boy in it.
When local people opened the pot, there was a pretty boy in it.

sen.j: その後、その男の子は小船に乗って播磨の国に渡り、大荒明神になった。
sen.e: Later the boy rode a boat to Harima Province and became Osake myojin (God of Osake).
sen.cmt: 前出列の現代語文で、同内容です。
sen.e: Later the boy rode a small boat to Harima Province and became Osake myojin (God of Osake).
Later the boy rode a small boat to Harima Province and became Osake myojin (God of Osake).

sen.j: これらの伝説も、庵戸宮が桃太郎ゆかりの地であると知られる由縁となっている。
sen.e: These legends are also the origin that Ioto no miya is known as a place associated with Momotaro.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: These legends are also the base that Ioto no miya is known as a place associated with Momotaro.
These legends are also the base that Ioto no miya is known as a place associated with Momotaro.

sen.j: （ただし、前述のように『記紀』の信頼性を疑う見方や、あくまで後世の創作物であることから、桃太郎伝説の由来については本項と異なる説が全国に複数存在する）。
sen.e: (However, as described above, there is the view that doubts the credibility of the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" and the legends are creation in later years after all, there are several theories different from this article about the origin the legend of Momotaro across the country.)
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: (However, as previously described, there are the views and opinions across the country that doubt the credibility of the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" or that are different from this article about the origin the legend of Momotaro since the legends are creation in later years after all.

(However, as previously described, there are the views and opinions across the country that doubt the credibility of the "Kojiki" and the "Nihonshoki" or that are different from this article about the origin the legend of Momotaro since the legends are creation in later years after all.

tit.j: 卑弥呼の誕生地としての伝説
tit.e: Legends about the birthplace of Himiko
Legends about the birthplace of Himiko
Legends about the birthplace of Himiko

sen.j: 邪馬台国が近畿地方にあったとする説を採用する場合、孝霊天皇の皇女倭迹迹日百襲姫命（やまとととひももそひめのみこと）を卑弥呼とする説が有力（諸説あり）であることから、その皇女倭迹迹日百襲姫命の故郷である庵戸宮が卑弥呼ゆかりの地とされる。
sen.e: If the theory that Yamataikoku was in Kinki region is adopted, the theory that Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, the princess of Emperor Korei, was Himiko can be widely accepted (although various opinions exist), so that Ioto no miya that was the home of the princess Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto is believed as a place associated with Himiko.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Under the adaption of the theory that the Yamatai-koku kingdom was located in Kinki region, the theory that Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, the princess of Emperor Korei, was Himiko can be widely accepted (although various opinions exist), so that Ioto no miya, the home of the Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, is believed as a place associated with Himiko.

Under the adaption of the theory that the Yamatai-koku kingdom was located in Kinki region, the theory that Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, the princess of Emperor Korei, was Himiko can be widely accepted (although various opinions exist), so that Ioto no miya, the home of the Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, is believed as a place associated with Himiko.

sen.j: （ただし、特に邪馬台国および卑弥呼の正体についてはとりわけ激しい論争の的となることが多く、前述の桃太郎伝説と共にその信憑性が問題視される。）
sen.e: (However, Yamataikoku and identity of Himiko often became a controversial topic of especially heated debates and reliability of the legends is questionable as similar to above described the legend of Momotaro.)
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: (However, especially the Yamatai-koku and Himiko's identity often became the subject of fiercer debate and the reliability is questionable as similar to the previously mentioned legend of Momotaro.)
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: (However, especially the Yamatai-koku and Himiko's identity often became the subject of fiercer debate and the reliability is questionable as similar to the previously mentioned legend of Momotaro.)

sen.j: 庵戸神社の隣には、庵戸池（黒田池）と呼ばれる池がある。
sen.e: There is a pond called Ioto-ike pond (Kuroda-ike pond) next to Ioto Shrine.
There is a pond called Ioto-ike pond (also known as Kuroda-ike pond) next to Ioto-jinja Shrine.
There is a pond called Ioto-ike pond (also known as Kuroda-ike pond) next to Ioto-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: また、その周辺には弥生時代の黒田遺跡や唐古・鍵遺跡、箸墓古墳、古墳時代（6世紀）の前方後円墳である黒田大塚古墳等がある。
sen.e: In the neighborhood area, there are several relics, such as Kuroda site and Karako-Kagi site in the Yayoi period, Hashihaka tomb, and Kuroda Otsuka Tumulus, which is a keyhole-shaped mound built in Kofun period (tumulus period, 6th century.)

In the neighborhood area, there are several relics, such as Kuroda site and Karako-Kagi site in the Yayoi period, Hashihaka-kofun Tumulus, and Kuroda Otsuka-kofun Tumulus, which is a keyhole-shaped mound, built in Kofun period (tumulus period, sixth century).

In the neighborhood area, there are several relics, such as Kuroda site and Karako-Kagi site in the Yayoi period, Hashihaka-kofun Tumulus, and Kuroda Otsuka-kofun Tumulus, which is a keyhole-shaped mound, built in Kofun period (tumulus period, sixth century).

sen.j: さらに、門前の街道は聖徳太子が飛鳥から法隆寺へ通った「太子道」(筋違道)であると伝えられている。
sen.e: Further, the road before the shrine is told Taishimichi (or Sujikaimichi Road), the road where Prince Shotoku commuted from Asuka to Horyu-ji Temple.
Further, the road before the shrine is told 'Taishimichi' (also known as Sujikaimichi Road), the road where Prince Shotoku commuted from Asuka to Horyu-ji Temple.
Further, the road before the shrine is told 'Taishimichi' (also known as Sujikaimichi Road), the road where Prince Shotoku commuted from Asuka to Horyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 庵戸神社：近畿日本鉄道 近鉄田原本線 黒田駅 (奈良県)下車 南へ徒歩数分（約250ｍ）
sen.e: to Ioto Shrine: a few minutes walk to south (about 250 m) from Kuroda Station on Kintetsu Tawaramoto Line of Kintetsu Railway (Nara Prefecture)
Ioto-jinja Shrine: A few minutes' walk to south (about 250 meters) from Kuroda Station (Nara Prefecture) on Kintetsu Tawaramoto Line of Kintetsu Railway
Ioto-jinja Shrine: A few minutes' walk to south (about 250 meters) from Kuroda Station (Nara Prefecture) on Kintetsu Tawaramoto Line of Kintetsu Railway

sen.j: 法楽寺（旧宮跡）：同駅下車 西へ徒歩数分（約200ｍ）
sen.e: to Horaku-ji Temple (the old palace site): a few minutes walk to west (about 200 m) from the Station
Horaku-ji Temple (the old palace site): A few minutes' walk to west (about 200 meters) from the Kuroda Station
Horaku-ji Temple (the old palace site): A few minutes' walk to west (about 200 meters) from the Kuroda Station
